captions.text:
There are numerous military conflicts, border
disputes and all out wars happening right

now. With all of these international conflicts
comes the question of escalation. How far

will they go? Could any one of these conflicts
escalate enough to cause a nuclear war? To

answer that we first have to look at which
countries actually have nuclear weapons.

As of now, there are 8 states known to have
nuclear weapons. And they fall into two categories.

Countries that have signed the Treaty on the
Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, or NPT,

and countries that have not. The US, Russia,
The UK, France, and China have all signed

the NPT. These five countries have agreed
to stop making nuclear bombs. They’ve also

agreed to destroy their current stockpile
over time. The treaty has the lofty goal of

a nuclear weapon free world. But the treaty
is not enforced by any one governing body,

and the five states are basically under the
honor system, so progress is slow if moving
at all.

Then we have the three nuclear-capable countries
with bombs that are not part of the NPT: India,

Pakistan and Israel. These countries refused
to sign the treaty before it was put into

effect in 1970, primarily because it capped
the number of countries who were allowed to

have nuclear weapons at five. The five countries
that already had them. These three countries

had not yet developed their nuclear programs.
India tested their first nuclear weapon in

1974 and Pakistan tested theirs in 1995. Israel
has not confirmed or denied having a nuclear

arsenal and there is no solid evidence of
them testing a bomb, but according to the

Federation of American Scientists, Israel
may have as many as 80 nuclear weapons.

There are also countries that might be pursuing
nuclear weapons. Iran has a nuclear program,

but they claim it is for energy use only.
After a series of embargos and sanctions,

Iran has agreed to scale their program down.
But they also recently missed a deadline with

the U.N. to provide specific information pertaining
to their nuclear explosion experiments, so

we can’t really be sure what their current
status is.

North Korea, who withdrew from the NPT in
2003, has conducted three nuclear tests and

is said to have enough plutonium for 6-10
warheads. But have yet to develop a functional

nuclear weapon, we think. North Korea doesn’t
share information so no one really knows how
close they are.

So, with all that said, how worried should
we be about a nuclear war? Well, India and

China have a “no first use” policy, meaning
they won’t use nuclear weapons unless they

are attacked with one first. The UK has stated
they won’t use their nuclear weapons unless

an enemy state uses a WMD against their troops.
The U.S. is vague about it but claims to have

nuclear weapons as a deterrent. Russia dropped
their no first use policy in 1993, and now

claims that they will only use their nuclear
weapons if the Russian Federation is under

threat. France and Pakistan have policies
similar to Russia’s. Which just leaves Israel,

who has not made an official policy yet, because
they haven’t officially acknowledged that

they even have nukes. But that doesn’t change
the narrative.

No one wants to be the first nation to strike.
Using a nuclear weapon in this day and age

would bring large scale retribution from the
international community, and possible nuclear

counter strikes. As it stands now, the main
argument for nuclear weapons is to prevent

attacks by nuclear weapons. Add in all the
agencies actively monitoring and preventing

the proliferation of nukes, the successful
dismantling of Libya’s nuclear program in

2004, South Africa intentionally dismantling
their own program and weapons in 1991, Israel

eliminating Syria’s nuclear reactor by bombing
their facilities in 2007, and the threat seems
even less real.

If you still have questions about world conflicts
please check out our world at war playlist

to get an update on situations like the war
in Syria or Iraq. If you found this video

informative please subscribe. It is a great
way to support the show.

comments.text:
Was this a class project  or just some joke.

What reality does this garbage come from. The  US military strategic 
command twice requested a nuclear strike during the war of aggression 
against Vietnam and Korea. The only reason it was put off the table was 
because the public outcry would literally see the public jump the white 
house lawn and storm that government building. 

The definition of what is a considered a "conflict" has been so convoluted 
and ambiguous, that to singularly use the term "war" in a conclusive 
narrative is mute. These countries are giving a generalized definition of 
what they considered an attack to be. India and Russia reserved the right 
to deploy a first strike strategy should any military action is taken 
against them. Russia pulled out of this agreement because they are 
witnessing the continuous expansion of NATO literally to their door step. 
As a military strategy to implement a first strike solution is perhaps 
their only security measure from what is a full European invasion. To show 
their lack of fear against any Russian threat. NATO has continuously 
violate treaty after treaty without any reprisal. 

British military strategy is that if a Weapon of Mass Destruction is used 
against their "troops". Again, this is ambiguous. Weapon of Mass 
Destruction is so vaguely defined by both the United Nation and the British 
government. Weapons of Mass Destruction could literally include anything 
the British government deeds a weapon of Mass Destruction. Also, "troops" 
not troops at home, But, troops, which could included troops stationed 
anywhere or deployed anywhere.

The US reserved the right to use their nuclear weapon as a deterrent. A 
deterrent is also so vaguely defined that the deterrent could be as the 
British policy have it an attack against their troops at any of their 700 
bases across the globe and deployed almost equally.

We delude ourselves to assume that the lunatics in other countries are 
somehow different from the lunatics in our countries. These individuals are 
poised with their finger over that button ready and willing to press it at 
any given moment and your presence or existence as civilians annoys them to 
their core and more so despise the idiots you elect to tell them what to do 
and when to do it. 

Each day is another day to give thanks.﻿

comments.text:
+Guus Moors Well actually, there was. The US needed to force a surrender, 
but I'll get to why later. One of the biggest misconceptions about the 
Pacific Theatre was that the US bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki were the 
final nail in the coffin for Japan. It was not. Rather, the threat of 
Soviet Invasion loomed over them, as the Soviets stormed Manchukuo (also 
known as Manchuria), preparing for invasion. and the United States couldn't 
allow the Soviets to gain that amount of power, and control over the 
Japanese Islands. Therefore, the nuclear bombings were to force a surrender 
on US terms, as opposed to a surrender on Soviet terms. Even during World 
War 2, the Western Allies (US, France, Britain, etc.) and the Soviets were 
trying to gain the upper hand on each other. Another example of said 
conflict between the Allies was Operation Unthinkable. Look it up, I'm too 
lazy t say what it is.

comments.text:
People always blame the U.S. for Middle East problems. When the U.S. hardly 
did anything to start problems. The British (UK) (and UN), Iraq, even 
Russia, and Israel (couple others too) contribute to a lot of the chaos 
but... Some have contributed to end these problems.

The British constantly went in and out of the Middle East claiming 
territory, and the Arabs (mostly) were mad that they had control of what 
they thought was their territory (foreign control is a huge problem to 
extremists, and this terrorist organizations are created). Not to mention 
they promised both Israel and the Arabs a homeland which they did not keep. 
The Balfour declaration stated that Jews could have a homeland in 
Palestine. The UN kept backing Israel in wars and this angered the Arabs. 
Chaos and terror groups created

When USSR (Russia today) invaded Afghanistan in 1979 for the sole purpose 
to spread communism, the Afghans were infuriated and thus the rebel group, 
the Taliban, was created. They wanted to drive USSR troops out of 
Afghanistan, but thy still exists today terrorizing. They claim they want

comments.text:
Brazil and Argentina are nuclear capable countrys which signed the NPT. In 
the '80s Argentina military started to consider arming nuclear weapons 
after the UK carried tactical nukes to the South Atlantic during 1982's and 
the fear that they might have bombed Cordoba city if a carrier would be 
sunk in the conflict. So Brazil followed to make nuclear warheads to 
counter balance Argentina if that scenary makes real.
In the late 1980s, ealry 1990 Argentina and Brazil created a binational 
organization to control the nuclear programs of each other and signed a 
resignation to further persuit in nuclear weapons but keeping the complete 
cicle for making the bombs. So today Argentina and Brazil are nuclear 
capable countrys with mines, enrichment plants, technology and capabilitys 
to make nuclear warheads but have self resigned to make em, but they can 
activate em in case of inminent danger from extracontinental menaces if 
needed in a short period of time.
The International Agency of Atomic Energy DOES NOT controls both countrys 
directly as in the rest of the world, instead each country controls the 
other and submit reports to it.﻿
